quiz.title: Grade 12 Advanced Mechanics
quiz.subtitle: Unit 3, Quiz 7: Mixed Problems - SHM & Waves
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: What is the frequency of vibration if the balance wheel of a wrist watch makes 90 revolutions in 25 s?

Which of the following motions is simple harmonic? I. The motion of tyres of a moving car, II. The motion of a loaded test tube oscillated vertically, III. The beating of the heart, IV. A stone tied to a string whirled round, V. The motion of the pistons in a gasoline engine.
questions.explanation: Simple Harmonic Motion requires a restoring force proportional to displacement. A loaded test tube (II) and pistons (V) are classic SHM. The heart (III) is often classified as periodic/harmonic in physics contexts. Circular motion (IV) and tire rotation (I) are not SHM.

questions.question: The wavelength of a wave traveling with a velocity of $420 \text{ ms}^{-1}$ is $42 \text{ m}$. What is its period?
questions.explanation: First find frequency: $f = \frac{v}{\lambda} = \frac{420}{42} = 10 \text{ Hz}$. Then period: $T = \frac{1}{f} = \frac{1}{10} = 0.1 \text{ s}$.

questions.question: A bob of weight $0.1 \text{ N}$ hangs from a string of length $50 \text{ cm}$. It is pulled until the string makes an angle of $60^\circ$ with the vertical. The work done is?
questions.explanation: Work done $W = mgh$, where $h = L(1 - \cos\theta)$. $h = 0.5(1 - \cos60^\circ) = 0.5 \times 0.5 = 0.25 \text{ m}$. $W = 0.1 \times 0.25 = 0.025 \text{ J}$.

questions.question: Given the pendulum formula $T = 2\pi\sqrt{L/g}$, which of the following graphs are linear? i) $T$ vs $L$, ii) $T$ vs $L^2$, iii) $T^2$ vs $L$, iv) $T$ vs $\sqrt{L}$, v) $\log T$ vs $\log L$.
questions.explanation: $T^2$ vs $L$ is linear ($T^2 = \frac{4\pi^2}{g}L$). $T$ vs $\sqrt{L}$ is linear ($T \propto \sqrt{L}$). $\log T$ vs $\log L$ is linear ($\log T = \frac{1}{2}\log L + \text{constant}$).

questions.question: A siren with 200 holes makes $132 \text{ rev/min}$. Calculate the wavelength if sound speed is $350 \text{ m/s}$.
The motion of a body is simple harmonic if the?
options: acceleration is always directed towards a fixed point
acceleration is proportional to the square of displacement
questions.explanation: The defining condition of SHM is $a = -\omega^2 x$, meaning acceleration is proportional to displacement and always directed toward the equilibrium point.

questions.question: A mass of $2 \text{ kg}$ is swung in a circular path (radius $1.2 \text{ m}$) at $120 \text{ rev/min}$. Find the tension in the rope.
questions.explanation: Angular velocity $\omega = 120 \times \frac{2\pi}{60} = 4\pi \text{ rad/s}$. Tension $T = m\omega^2 r = 2 \times (4\pi)^2 \times 1.2 = 2 \times 16\pi^2 \times 1.2 \approx 379 \text{ N}$.

questions.question: A pendulum has a period of $5.77 \text{ s}$. When shortened by $3 \text{ m}$, the period is $4.60 \text{ s}$. Calculate the new length.
A particle executes SHM with amplitude $A$ and period $T$. What is the time taken to travel from $x = 0$ to $x = A/2$?
questions.explanation: Using $x = A\sin(\omega t)$ for motion starting at equilibrium. Set $A/2 = A\sin(\omega t) \Rightarrow \sin(\omega t) = 0.5 \Rightarrow \omega t = \pi/6 \Rightarrow t = (\pi/6)/\omega = (\pi/6) \times (T/2\pi) = T/12$.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You've demonstrated strong problem-solving skills across diverse SHM and wave problems, from calculations to conceptual understanding.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Solid application of SHM formulas and wave equations. Review the graphical relationships for pendulums and the time calculations in SHM cycles.
scoreMessages.50: Fair. Focus on: 1) Distinguishing SHM from other periodic motions, 2) Applying $T = 2\pi\sqrt{L/g}$ and $v = f\lambda$, 3) Energy/work calculations in pendulums, 4) Circular motion to SHM connections.
scoreMessages.0: Start with the fundamentals: Review the defining equation of SHM ($a = -\omega^2 x$), pendulum and spring formulas, wave relationships ($v = f\lambda$), and energy conservation in oscillations.
